## ROP Target Update Notebook ‚Äì Deep‚ÄëDive Technical Documentation

Related Notebook: [ROP_Update](https://adb-7193294504864202.2.azuredatabricks.net/editor/notebooks/4291862458712398?o=7193294504864202#command/3733438010569264)

The purpose of the ROP¬†(Re‚ÄëOrder‚ÄëPoint)¬†Update notebook is to take the customer‚Äôs option‚Äëlevel ROP proposals,¬†cleanse and enrich them with internal performance, stock and scope metrics, and treat new‚Äëline items (`New¬†Line¬†Flag¬†=¬†1`) through a separate launch algorithm.
For every size¬†(`ProductCode`) within every style¬†(`OptionCode`) and store, the notebook produces an adjusted, validated ROP split‚Äîthen writes those targets to Delta¬†Lake tables that drive replenishment engines and dashboards.

If we pushed the raw customer file straight through we could introduce

ment engines and dashboards.

If we pushed the raw customer file straight through we could introduce

- duplicate Option√óStore√óSize rows,
- unrealistic validity dates,
- ignorance of real performance signals (sales, store stock, WH¬†+¬†GIT),
- corruption of downstream critical‚Äëstock logic, and
- mis‚Äëallocations for brand‚Äënew sizes with no history.

To avoid those risks the notebook performs two parallel pipelines:

brand‚Äënew sizes with no history.

To avoid those risks the notebook performs two parallel pipelines:

| Pipeline | Applies to | Core steps |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Existing sizes (New¬†Line¬†Flag¬†=¬†0) | Styles/sizes with ‚â•1 historical sale | 1¬†Ingest CSV ‚Üí 2¬†Join 6‚Äëmonth sales, WH¬†+¬†GIT, store stock, merchandising curves ‚Üí 3¬†Compute sales, stock and SS ratios ‚Üí 4¬†Pick best ratio ‚Üí 5¬†Normalise so Œ£¬†ratio =¬†1 per Option√óStore ‚Üí 6¬†final_q = round( ratio¬†√ó¬†Suggested¬†QT ). |
| New‚Äëline sizes (New¬†Line¬†Flag¬†=¬†1) | Styles/sizes with zero history | 1¬†Ingest CSV ‚Üí 2¬†Join WH usable stock & merchandising size curves ‚Üí 3¬†Use curve (fallback WH share) for ratio ‚Üí 4¬†Normalise ratios ‚Üí 5¬†final_q = round( ratio¬†√ó¬†Suggested¬†QT ) ‚Üí 6¬†Diff‚Äëcheck ¬±1 and calibration loop to cap orders by WH inventory. |

After ratios are resolved the notebook:

ck ¬±1 and calibration loop to cap orders by WH inventory. |

After ratios are resolved the notebook:

1. Normalises splits so each Option√óStore totals exactly the customer‚Äôs Suggested¬†QT.
2. Buckets rows into Min /¬†Fix /¬†Max target types.
3. Persists them to Delta¬†Lake (/min_target/, /fix_target/, /max_target/).
4. Updates critical_stock accordingly and appends any new Product√óStore pairs to scope_addition.csv.

In short, both historical and new‚Äëline items are rigorously validated, performance‚Äëweighted, inventory‚Äëcalibrated and written to governed Delta tables‚Äîprotecting data integrity while aligning with customer expectations.

# 3¬†¬†Size Break Logics Revisited

With the Option¬†>¬†Product hierarchy, every size (¬†`ProductCode`¬†) attached to a style (¬†`OptionCode`¬†) receives up to five independent weighting signals:

oductCode`¬†) attached to a style (¬†`OptionCode`¬†) receives up to five independent weighting signals:

| Signal | How it is calculated | When it is used |
| --- | --- | --- |
| size_perf_ratio | Store‚Äëlevel 6‚Äëmonth sales of the size √∑ total option sales in the same store. | First choice for historical sizes (¬†New¬†Line¬†Flag¬†=¬†0¬†). |
| size_stock_perf_ratio | Store‚Äëlevel stock (WH¬†+¬†store) of the size √∑ total option stock in the store. | Blended into SS weight. |
| size_ss_perf_ratio | Mean of sales‚Äë and stock‚Äëratios when both exist; otherwise whichever exists. | Feed into norm_size_perf_ratio after SS‚Äëthreshold filter. |
| WH_size_ratio | Usable WH inventory of the size √∑ total usable WH inventory of its option. | Fallback for both historical and new‚Äëline items. |
| normalized_share | Merchandising size curve share for the product‚Äëgroup, size and country, renormalised so Œ£¬†share¬†=¬†1 per Option√óStore. | Primary driver for new‚Äëline items; secondary fallback for historical ones. |

=¬†1 per Option√óStore. | Primary driver for new‚Äëline items; secondary fallback for historical ones. |

Selection hierarchy

*For historical sizes (*`New¬†Line¬†Flag¬†=¬†0`*):*

1. norm_size_perf_ratio (SS ratio after threshold/boost)
2. normalized_share
3. WH_size_ratio

*For new‚Äëline sizes (*`New¬†Line¬†Flag¬†=¬†1`*):*

1. normalized_share
2. WH_size_ratio

After a signal is chosen, all ratios are re‚Äëscaled so they sum to¬†1 inside each Option¬†√ó¬†Store, guaranteeing the split matches the customer‚Äôs `Suggested¬†QT`.

# Parent-Child Capacity Capping Logic

### Context

In our transfer planning workflow, stores may have nested capacity constraints defined at both child (specific group) and parent (broader group) levels. A given store might have multiple child capacity groups under a shared parent capacity group (e.g. different shoe types under "Shoes").

To prevent exceeding the parent-level capacity due to over-allocation across children, we apply a proportional capping mechanism that ensures each child receives a fair and bounded share of the parent‚Äôs capacity.

---

### Objective

Prevent total child group capacity from exceeding the available capacity of the parent group, while maintaining the relative proportions of capacity across child groups.

---

### Step-by-Step Logic

#### 1. Calculate final available capacity at child level

Each child capacity group has its own `final_available_capacity`, calculated as:

ity at child level

Each child capacity group has its own `final_available_capacity`, calculated as:

`final_available_capacity = max(CapacityLimit - CurrentCapacity, 0) / ShipmentValue `

This gives us how many additional units the group can accept based on its own limits.

---

#### 2. Calculate total available across all children of the same parent

Group by `(StoreCode, ParentCapacityGroupCode)` and sum the `final_available_capacity` across all relevant children:

`total_child_capacity = Œ£(final_available_capacity) `

---

#### 3. Apply Proportional Scaling

If the parent‚Äôs available capacity is less than the sum of all children‚Äôs:

`final_available_capacity_capped = parent_capacity * (     child_final_available_capacity / total_child_capacity ) `

This ensures:

- The total capped capacity of children doesn‚Äôt exceed the parent‚Äôs.
- The relative distribution remains consistent.

If no parent capping is needed, fallback to:

ent‚Äôs.
- The relative distribution remains consistent.

If no parent capping is needed, fallback to:

`final_available_capacity_capped = final_available_capacity `

---

### Example

| Store | Parent Group | Child Group | Final Available Capacity |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| A | SHOES | LADIES | 6 |
| A | SHOES | MEN | 4 |
| A | SHOES | Total | 10 |
| A | SHOES (Limit) |  | 5 |

Capped Capacity:

- LADIES ‚Üí 5 √ó (6/10) = 3
- MEN ‚Üí 5 √ó (4/10) = 2

---

### Benefits

- Eliminates overflows on parent capacity groups.
- Maintains fairness ‚Äî allocations reflect original availability.
- Does not require additional heuristics or manual weights.

---

### Where It‚Äôs Applied

This logic is implemented in the `save_blocked_store_capacity()` and `save_blocked_store_capacity_debug()` methods under the `CccBlocked` class. The `final_available_capacity_capped` field stores the adjusted child-level capacities.

## ‚úÖ PART 2: WHY THE LOOP?

### The loop ensures iterative cleanup because:

1. After deleting some results, new violations might emerge.For example, you delete Option A which fixes Store 101, but now Store 102 exceeds its final_available_capacity_capped_prop because some constraints are dependent.
2. Interdependencies between MinCost and Capacity:Normally, one would not expect any capacity related deletions after the first iteration. However, deleting low-cost shipments may allow more transfers to remain which may increase capacity usage of some stores, so when we iterate through the loop, new deletions based on capacity may emerge.Or vice versa: removing something for Capacity might make something invalid for MinCost (if the value drops below the threshold).
3. ‚ùó #deleteNew is re-evaluated at the end of every loop:SET @Problem = (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM #deleteNew) If any new "MinShipmentCost" violations occur after earlier deletions, they‚Äôll be re-evaluated and marked again.

`Step 1: Calculate capacity pressure ‚Üí #ResultsNewForCapacity  `

`Step 2: Identify violations ‚Üí #DeleteforRuleCapacity  `

`Step 3: Try to fix with ONE option ‚Üí #SolvedwithOneOptionForCapacity  `

`Step 4: Try to fix with MULTIPLE options (cumsum) ‚Üí #SolvedwithMultipleOptionForCapacity  Step 5: Gather all to delete ‚Üí #DeleteResults_forCapacityLimit  `

`Step 6: Delete from #transferresults  `

`Step 7: Re-check for other violations (loop again if needed) `

---

## ‚úÖ Final Notes

- üí° You use cumsum and row_number() ranking to minimize deletions while still solving the capacity constraint.
- üîÅ You loop until no more #deleteNew rows exist, meaning:All MinCost issues are resolvedAnd any changes caused by previous deletions are fully cleaned up.
